basics.title: Options Trading Basics
basics.what_are_options_desc: Options are financial derivatives that give the buyer the right (but not the obligation) to buy or sell an underlying asset at a predetermined price (strike) before or on a specific date (expiration).
basics.call_option_desc: A call option gives the buyer the right to buy the underlying asset at the strike price. Buyers profit from rising prices.
basics.put_option_desc: A put option gives the buyer the right to sell the underlying asset at the strike price. Buyers profit from falling prices.
basics.strike_price_desc: The predetermined price at which the underlying asset can be bought or sold when the option is exercised.
basics.expiration_desc: The date by which the option can be exercised. After this date, the option expires worthless if not exercised.
basics.premium_desc: The price the buyer pays for the option. The premium consists of intrinsic value and time value.

strategies.title: Options Strategies
strategies.covered_call_desc: You own the underlying asset and sell a call option. Strategy to generate additional income with neutral to slightly bullish market expectations.
strategies.protective_put_desc: You own the underlying asset and buy a put option as insurance against falling prices.
strategies.iron_condor_desc: Combination of bull put spread and bear call spread. Profitable in low volatility and sideways trending markets.
strategies.bull_spread_desc: Buy a call option with lower strike and sell a call option with higher strike. Limited profit potential with rising prices.
strategies.bear_spread_desc: Buy a put option with higher strike and sell a put option with lower strike. Limited profit potential with falling prices.
strategies.straddle_desc: Simultaneous purchase of a call and put option with the same strike and expiration. Profits from strong price movements in either direction.

risks.title: Risks & Opportunities
risks.leverage_desc: Options provide leverage that amplifies both gains and losses. A small capital investment can control large positions.
risks.total_loss_desc: Option buyers can lose their entire premium if the option expires worthless.
risks.unlimited_risk_desc: Sellers of uncovered call options face theoretically unlimited risk, as the price of the underlying can rise indefinitely.
risks.income_desc: By selling options (e.g., covered calls), regular income can be generated.
risks.hedging_desc: Options are excellent for hedging existing positions against price losses.
risks.flexibility_desc: Options enable diverse strategies for different market scenarios and risk profiles.

regulation.title: Regulation in Germany
regulation.bafin_desc: BaFin supervises the German financial market and licenses brokers. All brokers operating in Germany must be licensed by BaFin or have an EU passporting license.
regulation.mifid: MiFID II (Markets in Financial Instruments Directive)
regulation.mifid_desc: EU-wide directive for investor protection. Brokers must inform clients about risks, assess suitability, and provide transparent cost statements.
regulation.esma_desc: The European Securities and Markets Authority (ESMA) has introduced restrictions for retail investors, e.g., for CFDs. Fewer restrictions apply to traditional options.
regulation.investor_protection_desc: Deposit insurance up to €100,000 with EU-regulated brokers. Segregation of client funds is mandatory.

taxes.title: Taxation of Options in Germany
taxes.capital_gains_tax_desc: Profits from options trading are subject to the capital gains tax of 25% (plus solidarity surcharge 5.5% and possibly church tax). Total approx. 26.375%.
taxes.allowance_desc: Every investor has a tax-free allowance of €1,000 per year (€2,000 for married couples). Profits up to this amount are tax-free.
taxes.loss_offset_desc: Losses from options trading can be offset against gains from capital investments. Losses can be carried forward to the following year.
taxes.reporting_desc: German brokers automatically withhold taxes. With foreign brokers, profits must be declared in the tax return (Annex KAP).
taxes.tax_example_desc: With a profit of €5,000 (after deducting the allowance of €1,000): €4,000 × 26.375% = €1,055 tax liability.

glossary.title: Options Glossary
glossary.atm_def: An option whose strike price equals the current price of the underlying asset.
glossary.itm_def: An option with intrinsic value. For calls: price > strike. For puts: price < strike.
glossary.otm_def: An option without intrinsic value. For calls: price < strike. For puts: price > strike.
glossary.implied_volatility_def: The market's expected future fluctuation of the underlying asset, derived from the option price.
glossary.theta_def: Metric for the daily value loss of an option due to time passage. Negative for buyers, positive for sellers.
glossary.delta_def: Indicates how much the option price changes when the underlying moves by €1. Values between 0 and 1 (calls) or 0 and -1 (puts).
glossary.gamma_def: Rate of change of delta. Shows how quickly delta changes with price movements of the underlying.
glossary.vega_def: Sensitivity of the option price to changes in implied volatility.
glossary.assignment_def: The process where an option seller is obligated to fulfill their obligation (buy or sell the underlying asset).

faq.title: Frequently Asked Questions (FAQ)
faq.q1: How much capital do I need for options trading?
faq.a1: The minimum deposit varies by broker (€0 to €2,000). However, for meaningful diversification, you should plan for at least €5,000-10,000. Keep in mind that one option contract typically covers 100 shares.
faq.a2: Options are complex financial instruments with significant risks. Beginners should first educate themselves thoroughly, practice with a demo account, and start with simple strategies (e.g., covered calls). Education is essential.
faq.q3: What is the difference between European and American options?
faq.a3: European options can only be exercised on the expiration date. American options can be exercised at any time until expiration. Most stock options are American, index options are often European.
faq.q4: Do I have to hold options until expiration?
faq.a4: No. You can close option positions at any time before expiration through an offsetting transaction. Most traders close positions early to realize profits or limit losses.
faq.q5: How is the option premium calculated?
faq.a5: The option premium consists of: Intrinsic value (difference between stock price and strike) + Time value (influenced by remaining time, volatility, interest rates, and dividends). The Black-Scholes model is the best-known valuation model.
faq.q6: What happens if I don't have shares and an option is exercised?
faq.a6: If you sold an uncovered (naked) option and it's exercised, you must buy the shares at market price (for calls) or sell them (for puts). This can lead to significant losses. Therefore, margin requirements for uncovered options are high.
